descript.abstract: The mangrove file was created for the AWE Project being run by the Nature Conservancy. The dataset is complilation of many different datasets and contributors. The spatial information comes from five (5) different datasets. 1.) Contract work by Matthew Jones where he used existing data from LandSat and improved upon these shapes using Bing and ESRI imagery base maps. About 35% of the shapes by number are from this effort 2.) The Ph.D. work of Kim Baldwin at the University of the West Indies Cave Hill and the generation of the Marine Space-use Information System (MarSIS) resulted in a benthic habitat file which she created by heads up digitizing effort using IKONOS imagery. About 15% of the shapes by number are from this effort. 3.) Contractors of the Nature Conservancy working from BYU digitized from WorldView2 2010 orthophotos for Grenada. About 20% of the shapes by number are from this effort. 4.) Again, contractors of the Nature Conservancy working from BYU digitized from 2007 aerial imagery for St. Vincent adn the Grenadines. About 10% by number of the shapes are from this effort. Finally, 5.) field verification of mangrove patches by Gregg Moore of the University of New Hampshire has resulted in about 20% of the shapes by number. Gregg Moore has also been responsible for filling out the attributes of each feature which include dominant vegetation type and species richness.
descript.purpose: The majority of these data were created under the direction of The Nature Conservancy for the Ecosystem Based Adaptation in the Grenadine Bank project. This project is built on the hypothesis that the neighboring and ecologically connected small island states in the Grenadine Bank can enhance the resilience of people and nature to climate change impacts by protecting, restoring and sustainably managing marine and coastal systems and strengthening community capacity for adaptation.
